section.title: Purpose
section.para: It has been written to assist end users in installing the necessary tools for Tinkar and Komet environments. This guide will help with the installation of prerequisites, the establishment of a safe work environment, and the acquisition of data needed for these environments.

para.emphasis: Please, read this ENTIRE guide and follow the below and the appropriate steps, in-order, to be successful in setting up the necessary environments.

section.title: Git Setup
section.para: Git requires some basic setup before it is very useful – specifically setting the user’s email and name to identify commits as the user.
Set the user’s name:
git config --global user.name "John Doe"
Of course, replace “John Doe” with your own name.
Next, set your email address:
git config --global user.email "john.doe@domain.com"

Replace the example email address with your own. Tip – do not use your Deloitte email address as commits will be put on GitHub. Instead, either use your personal email address associated with your GitHub account (see later on) or a generated private email available within your GitHub profile settings page (Emails section – look for an item called “Keep my email private”).
Optional Settings
There are a few settings worth considering.
Using the “simple” push strategy by default:
git config --global push.default simple
Automatically setup remote branches upon pushing:
git config --global push.autoSetupRemote true
Setting the default branch to “main”:
git config --global init.defaultBranch main
Default editors
If you did not select a default text editor to use with Git, you can set this via the command line. Only choose one of the following.
Use VSCode as your default editor:
git config –global core.editor “code --wait”
Use Nano as your default editor:
git config –global core.editor nano

section.title: DEVELOPMENT ENVIRONMENT SET UP
section.para: Tinkarbuild is the environment we use to build our Integrated Knowledge Management (IKM) project called Tinkar (Terminology Knowledge Architecture). Tinkar is a logical model that aims to provide a foundation for a knowledge of architecture that will integrate local systems and medical and laboratory terminologies to support clinical information that can communicate effectively across multiple systems. The application we use to do this is called Komet.

section.title: KOMET ENVIRONMENT SET UP
section.para: Komet is our tool to achieve our goal of integrated knowledge management.

section.title: Clone Komet
section.para: To clone Komet, follow the steps below:

listitem.para: Go to https://github.com/ikmdev/komet website.
Navigate to the drop-down options under “<> Code”

Next clone (copy) the Komet Git repository (the HTTPS URL shown in the red box below) from GitHub and run it within the terminal (on macOS or Linux) OR Git Bash terminal (on Windows). This will put the repository at directory <username>/projects/komet.
Utilizing terminal (on macOS or Linux) OR Git Bash terminal (on Windows). Run the following commands one by one:
mkdir -p $HOME/projects
cd $HOME/projects
git clone https://github.com/ikmdev/komet.git

Note for Mac Users: On macOS after you run the above commands, you may then be prompted to install the Xcode developer tools. Accept the agreement to install the toolkit, and the git clone should finish.
After the Git clone is done, the respository folder can be found in the projects directory as shown below.

figure.title: Komet repository folder in projects directory

section.title: Build/Run Komet
section.para: To build & run Komet, follow the steps below:

listitem.para: Open a New Terminal (on macOS or Linux) or Git Bash Terminal (for Windows).
Run the below command:
mvn clean install
Once the above command has been run, run the following command list below:
mvn -f application javafx:run

section.title: Configure IntelliJ
section.para: Tonconfigure IntelliJ, you must:

listitem.para: Click "Open Project" within IntelliJ and navigate to the cloned project (i.e., ~/Code/komet)
Click "Trust Project"
Navigate to "File", follwoed by Project Structure"
Within the SDK dropdown, select the detected SDK in your case the Azul SDK we downloaded earlier
Select the language level that aligns with what we saw in Komet’s pom.xml (for example: 23 preview but your version may vary)
If prompted, you may ignore the "Read Me" instructions
Select "Run", followed by "Edit Configurations..."
Click 'Add new run configuration...' and select Applications
Click "Modify Options" and select "Add VM options"
NOTE: VM options shiftspositions when you click “modify options” then “add VM options”, so ensure you are pasting in VM options and NOT program arguments
Set up Run Configurations, as shown below, for IntelliJ to run Komet
For your convenience, you can copy and paste the VM args from here instead of retyping from the screenshot:
-Xmx10g --add-exports
javafx.controls/com.sun.javafx.scene.control.behavior=dev.ikm.komet.navigator --add-exports
javafx.base/com.sun.javafx.event=one.jpro.platform.file --add-exports javafx.base/com.sun.javafx.event=org.controlsfx.controls
Once Run Configuration is set up, ensure all run options are selected, similar to screenshot below within the "Add Run Options"
For the "Main Class" field click the “Browse” icon and then click the option “App of dev.ikm.komet.app”. After that click “ok:
Once run options have been selected, select "Apply" and then "OK"
To create the Maven, build first select the lower case "m" in the right-hand corner of the screen. Then click the "execute maven goal" icon.
After that type “mvn clean install -U -DskipTests -Dmaven.build.cache.skipCache=true -Dmaven.javadoc.skip=true” and hit enter. It will take around 5-10 minutes to install the first time.
Then click the green play button and IntelliJ set up is complete
Note: can click highlighted icon in blue to put mvn clean commands
Note: IntelliJ can get corrupted so must invalidate cache from time to time.
